pageContext.name: english
pageContext.prefixed:
<tei-TEI data-xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xmlns:xi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XInclude" data-origname="TEI" data-origatts="xmlns:xi xmlns">
 <tei-teiHeader data-origname="teiHeader">
      <tei-fileDesc data-origname="fileDesc">
        <tei-titleStmt data-origname="titleStmt">
           <tei-title data-origname="title">Monsieur Acarete du Biscay's Journey from Buenos Ayres to Peru</tei-title>
           <tei-author data-origname="author">Acarete du Biscay</tei-author>
        </tei-titleStmt>
        <tei-publicationStmt data-origname="publicationStmt">
           <tei-p data-origname="p">An Account of a voyage up the river de la Plata, and thence over land to Peru. With observations on the inhabitants, as well Indians and Spaniards; the cities, commerce, fertility, and riches of that part of America</tei-p>
        </tei-publicationStmt>
        <tei-sourceDesc data-origname="sourceDesc">
           <tei-bibl data-origname="bibl">
  <tei-title data-origname="title">Monsieur Acarete Du Biscay’s journey from Buenos Aires to Perú</tei-title>. In
 <tei-author data-origname="author">Du Biscay, Acarete</tei-author>. <tei-publisher data-origname="publisher">Voyages and Discoveries in South America, vol. II</tei-publisher>. <tei-editor data-origname="editor">S. Buckley. World Digital Library</tei-editor><tei-date data-origname="date">1698</tei-date>. </tei-bibl>
        </tei-sourceDesc>
      </tei-fileDesc>
      <tei-profileDesc data-origname="profileDesc">
         <tei-langUsage data-origname="langUsage">
            <tei-language ident="eng" data-origname="language" data-origatts="ident">English</tei-language>
            <tei-language ident="esp" data-origname="language" data-origatts="ident">Spanish</tei-language>
         </tei-langUsage>
      </tei-profileDesc>
 </tei-teiHeader>
 <tei-text data-origname="text">
   <tei-body data-origname="body">
   <tei-pb data-origname="pb" data-empty=""/>
   <tei-head data-origname="head"><tei-name data-origname="name">Monsieur Acarete du Biscay's</tei-name> Journey from <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Buenos Ayres</tei-placeName> to <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Peru</tei-placeName>
</tei-head>
     <tei-div data-origname="div">
         <tei-p data-origname="p">
            I Left <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Buenos Ayres</tei-placeName>, and took the Road I to 
            <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Cordoua</tei-placeName>, leaving <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Santa Fe</tei-placeName> on 
            my right hand, of which place take this account, <tei-abbr data-origname="abbr">'tis</tei-abbr> a Spanish Settlement 
            dependant upon <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Buenos Ayres</tei-placeName>, the Commander is no more than a Lieutenant, 
            and does nothing but by order from the Governor of <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Buenos Ayres</tei-placeName>. <tei-abbr data-origname="abbr">'Tis</tei-abbr> a 
            little place containing <tei-num type="cardinal" data-origname="num" data-origatts="type">25</tei-num> Houses, without any Walls, Fortifications, or 
            Garrison, distant <tei-num type="cardinal" data-origname="num" data-origatts="type">80</tei-num> Leagues from <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Buenos Ayres</tei-placeName> Northward, 
            <tei-choice data-origname="choice"><tei-sic data-origname="sic">Situate</tei-sic><tei-corr data-origname="corr">Situated</tei-corr></tei-choice> upon the 
            River <tei-geogName data-origname="geogName">de la Plata</tei-geogName>, large Vessels might come up to it, were it not for a 
            great bank that obstructs the passage a little above <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Buenos Ayres</tei-placeName>. 
            Nevertheless <tei-abbr data-origname="abbr">'tis</tei-abbr> a very advantageous Post, because <tei-abbr data-origname="abbr">'tis</tei-abbr> the only passage 
            from <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Peru</tei-placeName>, <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Chili</tei-placeName> and <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Tucuman</tei-placeName>
            to <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Paraguay</tei-placeName>, and in a manner the Magazine of the Commodi<tei-fw type="catch" data-origname="fw" data-origatts="type">ties</tei-fw>
            <tei-pb n="25" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="n" data-empty=""/>
            ties drawn from thence, particularly that Herb already spoken of, which they cannot be without in those Provinces. 
            The Soil is as good and Fertile here as at <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Buenos Ayres</tei-placeName>; and the Town having nothing 
            remarkably different from what has been <tei-abbr data-origname="abbr">observ'd</tei-abbr> of <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Buenos Ayres</tei-placeName>, I leave 
            it, and proceed upon my Journey. <tei-abbr data-origname="abbr">'Tis</tei-abbr> counted <tei-num type="cardinal" data-origname="num" data-origatts="type">140</tei-num> Leagues from <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Buenos 
            Ayres</tei-placeName> to <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Cordoua</tei-placeName>, and because some parts of the Road are uninhabited for a 
            long way together ; I furnished my self at my departure with what I was 
            <tei-abbr data-origname="abbr">inform'd</tei-abbr> I should stand in need of; so I set out having a Savage for my 
            Guide, with <tei-num type="cardinal" data-origname="num" data-origatts="type">Three</tei-num> Horses and <tei-num type="cardinal" data-origname="num" data-origatts="type">Three</tei-num> Mules, some to carry my Baggage, and 
            the rest to change upon the way when that I rid upon was tired.
         </tei-p>
         <tei-p data-origname="p">
            From <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Buenos Ayres</tei-placeName>, to the River <tei-geogName data-origname="geogName">Lucan</tei-geogName>, and even as far as the River 
            <tei-geogName data-origname="geogName">Recife</tei-geogName>, <tei-num type="cardinal" data-origname="num" data-origatts="type">30</tei-num> Leagues, I <tei-abbr data-origname="abbr">pass’d</tei-abbr> by several Habitations and Farms cultivated 
            by the Spaniards, but beyond <tei-geogName data-origname="geogName">Recife</tei-geogName> to the <tei-geogName data-origname="geogName">River Salladillo</tei-geogName>, I saw none. 
            Let it be observed by the way, that these Rivers as well as all the rest 
            in the Provinces of <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Buenos Ayres</tei-placeName>, <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Paraguay</tei-placeName> and <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Tucuman</tei-placeName>, that fall into the 
            River <tei-geogName data-origname="geogName">de la Plata</tei-geogName> are fordable on Horse-back; but when the Rains or <tei-fw type="catch" data-origname="fw" data-origatts="type">any</tei-fw>
            <tei-pb n="26" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="n" data-empty=""/> 
            other accident swells them, a Traveller must either swim over, or else get 
            upon a bundle in the nature of a raft, which a Savage hawls over to the 
            other side. I could not Swim, and so was <tei-abbr data-origname="abbr">forc'd</tei-abbr> to make use of this 
            expedient twice or thrice when I could not find a Ford. The way was this, 
            my Indian <tei-abbr data-origname="abbr">kill'd</tei-abbr> a Wild Bull, <tei-choice data-origname="choice"><tei-sic data-origname="sic">flead</tei-sic><tei-corr data-origname="corr">flayed</tei-corr></tei-choice> the Hide off, stuffed it with straw, 
            and <tei-abbr data-origname="abbr">ty'd</tei-abbr> it up in a great bundle with thongs of the same Hide, upon which 
            I <tei-abbr data-origname="abbr">plac'd</tei-abbr> my self with my Baggage ; he swam over <tei-sic data-origname="sic">hawling</tei-sic> me after him by a 
            Cord <tei-abbr data-origname="abbr">ty'd</tei-abbr> to the bundle, and then he <tei-abbr data-origname="abbr">repass'd</tei-abbr> and swam my Horses and Mules 
            over to me.
         </tei-p>
         <tei-p data-origname="p">
            All the Country between the River <tei-geogName data-origname="geogName">Recife</tei-geogName> and <tei-geogName data-origname="geogName">Salladillo</tei-geogName>, <tei-abbr data-origname="abbr">tho'</tei-abbr> uninhabited, 
            abounds in Cattle and all sorts of Fruit trees, except Walnut and Chesnut-
            trees; there are whole Woods of Nectarine-Trees, <tei-num type="cardinal" data-origname="num" data-origatts="type">Three</tei-num> or <tei-num type="cardinal" data-origname="num" data-origatts="type">Four</tei-num> Leagues in 
            compass, that bear excellent Fruit, which they not only eat raw, but bake 
            them, or dry them in the Sun, to keep, as we in <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">France</tei-placeName> do Prunes: They 
            seldom use any other than the Wood of this Tree for common firing at 
            <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Buenos Ayres</tei-placeName>, and thereabouts. The Savages that dwell in these Parts are 
            <tei-abbr data-origname="abbr">distinguish'd</tei-abbr> into <tei-num type="cardinal" data-origname="num" data-origatts="type">two</tei-num> sorts, those that <tei-fw type="catch" data-origname="fw" data-origatts="type">volunt-</tei-fw>
            <tei-pb n="27" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="n" data-empty=""/>            
            voluntarily submit to the 
            Spaniards are <tei-abbr data-origname="abbr">call’d</tei-abbr> <tei-name data-origname="name">Panpistas</tei-name>, the rest <tei-name data-origname="name">Serranos</tei-name>, both <tei-sic data-origname="sic">cloathed</tei-sic> with 
            Skins, but the last set up on the <tei-name data-origname="name">Panpistas</tei-name> as their mortal Enemies 
            wherever they meet with them. All Fight on Horse-back, either with Lances 
            pointed with Iron or Bones sharpen'd, or else with Bows and Arrows, they 
            wear Bulls-hides <tei-abbr data-origname="abbr">fashion'd</tei-abbr> like a Doublet without sleeves, to defend their 
            Bodies. Their Chiefs that command over them in War and Peace, are <tei-abbr data-origname="abbr">call’d</tei-abbr> 
            <tei-name data-origname="name">Couracas</tei-name>. When they take any one of their Enemies, alive or dead, they 
            meet all together, and after they have <tei-abbr data-origname="abbr">reproach'd</tei-abbr> him, that either he or 
            his Relations were the death of their Kindred or Friends, they cut and 
            tear him into pieces, which they roast a little and eat, making a drinking 
            Bowl of his <tei-choice data-origname="choice"><tei-sic data-origname="sic">Scull</tei-sic><tei-corr data-origname="corr">Skull</tei-corr></tei-choice>. They feed mostly upon flesh either raw or <tei-abbr data-origname="abbr">dress'd</tei-abbr>, and 
            particularly <tei-choice data-origname="choice"><tei-sic data-origname="sic">Colts</tei-sic><tei-corr data-origname="corr">Colt's</tei-corr></tei-choice> flesh, which they like better than Veal. They catch 
            abundance of Fish likewise in their Rivers. They have no settled places of 
            <tei-choice data-origname="choice"><tei-sic data-origname="sic">aboad</tei-sic><tei-corr data-origname="corr">abode</tei-corr></tei-choice>, but ramble up and down, several Families together, and live in Tents.
         </tei-p>
         <tei-p data-origname="p">
            I could not inform my self exactly what Religion they were of, but I was 
            told that they <tei-abbr data-origname="abbr">look'd</tei-abbr> upon the Sun and <tei-fw type="catch" data-origname="fw" data-origatts="type">Moon</tei-fw>
            <tei-pb n="28" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="n" data-empty=""/>
            Moon as Deities and as I <tei-abbr data-origname="abbr">travell'd</tei-abbr> along, I saw a Savage upon his knees 
            with his Face to the Sun, who <tei-abbr data-origname="abbr">cry'd</tei-abbr> out and made strange gestures with 
            his Hands and Arms. I <tei-abbr data-origname="abbr">learn'd</tei-abbr> from the Savage that <tei-abbr data-origname="abbr">accompany'd</tei-abbr> me, that 
            he was one of those they <tei-abbr data-origname="abbr">call'd</tei-abbr> <tei-name data-origname="name">Papas</tei-name>, who in the Morning kneel towards the Sun,
            and at Night towards the Moon, to supplicate those <tei-abbr data-origname="abbr">fancy'd</tei-abbr> Divinities 
            to be propitious to them, to give them fair Weather, and Victory over their Foes.
         </tei-p>
         <tei-p data-origname="p">
            They make no great Ceremony in their Marriages ; but when a Relation dies, 
            after they have <tei-abbr data-origname="abbr">rubb’d</tei-abbr> his body with a certain Earth that consumes all but 
            the Bones, they preserve them, and carry as many of them as they can 
            conveniently about with them in a sort of Chests, and this they do in 
            token of their affection to their Kindred ; indeed they are not wanting in 
            good Offices to them during their Lives, nor in their Sickness and Death.
         </tei-p>
         <tei-p data-origname="p">
            Along the River <tei-geogName data-origname="geogName">Salladillo</tei-geogName>, I took notice of a great many Parrats, or 
            <tei-name data-origname="name">Papagays</tei-name>, as the Spaniards call them, and certain Birds, <tei-abbr data-origname="abbr">call’d</tei-abbr> 
            <tei-name data-origname="name">Guacamayos</tei-name>, which are of divers Colours, and twice or thrice as big as a 
            Parrat. The River it self is <tei-fw type="catch" data-origname="fw" data-origatts="type">full</tei-fw>
            <tei-pb n="29" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="n" data-empty=""/>
            of the Fish, <tei-abbr data-origname="abbr">call'd</tei-abbr> <tei-name data-origname="name">Dorado</tei-name>, which is 
            very good to eat. There is also a Creature in it, whether <tei-abbr data-origname="abbr">'tis</tei-abbr> Meat or 
            <tei-choice data-origname="choice"><tei-sic data-origname="sic">Poyson</tei-sic><tei-corr data-origname="corr">Poison</tei-corr></tei-choice> no body knows, it has Four Feet and a long Tail like a Lizard.
         </tei-p>
         <tei-p data-origname="p">
            From <tei-geogName data-origname="geogName">Salladillo</tei-geogName> quite to <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Cordoua</tei-placeName>, you go along a very fine River, 
            that abounds with Fish, which is neither wide nor deep, for it may be forded 
            over. On the Bank of it you meet with little Plantations every Three or 
            Four Leagues ; which are like Country Houses inhabited by Spaniards, 
            Portuguese, and the Natives, who have all the necessary accomodations of 
            Life they can wish, and are very Civil and Charitable to Strangers; their 
            principal Wealth is in Horses and Mules, in which they Trade with the 
            Inhabitants of <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Peru</tei-placeName>.
         </tei-p>
         <tei-p data-origname="p">
            <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Cordoua</tei-placeName> is a Town <tei-choice data-origname="choice"><tei-sic data-origname="sic">Situate</tei-sic><tei-corr data-origname="corr">Situated</tei-corr></tei-choice>
            in a pleasant and fruitful Plain upon the side of a River, bigger and broader than that I have just spoken of : 
            <tei-abbr data-origname="abbr">'Tis</tei-abbr> <tei-abbr data-origname="abbr">compos’d</tei-abbr> of about <tei-num type="cardinal" data-origname="num" data-origatts="type">400</tei-num> Houses, Built like those of <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Buenos Ayres</tei-placeName>. It has 
            neither Ditches, nor Walls, nor Fort for its defence; He that Commands it 
            is Governor of all the Provinces of <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Tucuman</tei-placeName>, and <tei-abbr data-origname="abbr">tho’</tei-abbr> it be the place of 
            his ordinary Residence, yet he is wont now and then, as he sees oc<tei-fw type="catch" data-origname="fw" data-origatts="type">casion,</tei-fw>
            <tei-pb n="30" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="n" data-empty=""/>
            casion to go and pass some time at <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">St. Jago de l’Estro</tei-placeName>, at <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">St. Miguel de Tucuman</tei-placeName>, 
            (which is the Capital City of the Province) at <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Salta</tei-placeName> and at <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Xuxui</tei-placeName>. In each 
            of these Villages there is a Lieutenant, who has under him an Alcalde and 
            some Officers for the Administration of Justice. The Bishop of <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Tucuman</tei-placeName> 
            likewise usually resides at <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Cordoua</tei-placeName>, where the Cathedral is the only 
            Parish Church of the whole Town, but there are divers Convents of Monks, 
            namely of Dominicans, Recollects, and those of the <tei-name data-origname="name">Order de la Mercy</tei-name>: and 
            one of Nunns. The Jesuits have a College there, and their <tei-choice data-origname="choice"><tei-sic data-origname="sic">Chappel</tei-sic><tei-corr data-origname="corr">Chapel</tei-corr></tei-choice> is the 
            finest and richest of all.
         </tei-p>
         <tei-p data-origname="p">
            The Inhabitants are Rich in Gold and Silver, which they get by the Trade 
            they have for Mules, with which they furnish <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Peru</tei-placeName> and other Parts; which 
            is so considerable, that they sell about <tei-num type="cardinal" data-origname="num" data-origatts="type">28</tei-num> or <tei-num type="cardinal" data-origname="num" data-origatts="type">30000</tei-num> of <tei-abbr data-origname="abbr">'em</tei-abbr> every Year, 
            which they breed up in their Farms. They usually keep <tei-abbr data-origname="abbr">'em</tei-abbr> till they are 
            about <tei-num type="cardinal" data-origname="num" data-origatts="type">Two</tei-num> Years old, then expose <tei-abbr data-origname="abbr">'em</tei-abbr> to Sale, and have about <tei-num type="cardinal" data-origname="num" data-origatts="type">Six</tei-num> Patagons 
            a piece for <tei-abbr data-origname="abbr">'em</tei-abbr>. The Merchants that come to buy <tei-abbr data-origname="abbr">'em</tei-abbr>, carry <tei-abbr data-origname="abbr">'em</tei-abbr> to <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">St. 
            Jago</tei-placeName>, to <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Salta</tei-placeName> and <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Xuxui</tei-placeName>, 
            where they leave <tei-abbr data-origname="abbr">'em</tei-abbr> for <tei-num type="cardinal" data-origname="num" data-origatts="type">Three</tei-num> Years, till they are well grown and become <tei-fw type="catch" data-origname="fw" data-origatts="type">strong,</tei-fw> 
            <tei-pb n="31" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="n" data-empty=""/>
            and afterwards bring <tei-abbr data-origname="abbr">'em</tei-abbr> to <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Peru</tei-placeName>, where 
            they presently have Vent for <tei-abbr data-origname="abbr">'em</tei-abbr>, because there as well as in the rest of 
            the Western part of <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">America</tei-placeName>, the greatest part of their Carriage is upon 
            Mules. The People of <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Cordoua</tei-placeName> also drive a Trade in Cows, which they have 
            from the <tei-choice data-origname="choice"><tei-sic data-origname="sic">Countrey</tei-sic><tei-corr data-origname="corr">Country</tei-corr></tei-choice> of <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Buenos Ayres</tei-placeName>, and carry to <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Peru</tei-placeName>, where without this 
            way of Subsistance <tei-abbr data-origname="abbr">'tis</tei-abbr> certain they would have much ado to live. This 
            kind of Traffick makes this Town the most considerable in the Province of 
            <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Tucuman</tei-placeName>, as well for its Riches and Commodities, as for the Number of its 
            Inhabitants, which are counted to be at least <tei-num type="cardinal" data-origname="num" data-origatts="type">5</tei-num> or <tei-num type="cardinal" data-origname="num" data-origatts="type">600</tei-num> Families, besides 
            Slaves who are three times the number. But the generality of <tei-abbr data-origname="abbr">'em</tei-abbr> of all 
            degrees have no other Arms but a Sword and Poignard, and are very 
            indifferent <tei-choice data-origname="choice"><tei-sic data-origname="sic">Souldiers</tei-sic><tei-corr data-origname="corr">Soldiers</tei-corr></tei-choice>, the Air of the Country, and the Plenty they enjoy, 
            rendring them Lazy and Cowardly.
            </tei-p>
          </tei-div>
     </tei-body>
 </tei-text>
</tei-TEI>
